t: Proverbs 26
Like*pn snow in summer or rain in harvest, so*ld honor is not fitting for a fool.
Like*ln a sparrow in its flitting, like a swallow in its flying, a*ld curse that is causeless does not alight.
A*ln whip for the horse, a bridle for the donkey, and*ld a rod for the back of fools.
Answer*ln not a fool according to his folly, lest*ld you be like him yourself.
Answer*ln a fool according to his folly, lest*ld he be wise in his own eyes.
Whoever*ln sends a message by the hand of a fool cuts*ld off his own feet and drinks violence.
Like*ln a lame man’s legs, which hang useless, is*ld a proverb in the mouth of fools.
Like*ln one who binds the stone in the sling is*ld one who gives honor to a fool.
Like*ln a thorn that goes up into the hand of a drunkard is*ld a proverb in the mouth of fools.
Like*ln an archer who wounds everyone is*ld one who hires a passing fool or drunkard.
Like*ln a dog that returns to his vomit is*ld a fool who repeats his folly.
Do*ln you see a man who is wise in his own eyes? There*ld is more hope for a fool than for him.
The*ln sluggard says, “There is a lion in the road! There*ld is a lion in the streets!”
As*ln a door turns on its hinges, so*ld does a sluggard on his bed.
The*ln sluggard buries his hand in the dish; it*ld wears him out to bring it back to his mouth.
The*ln sluggard is wiser in his own eyes than*ld seven men who can answer sensibly.
Whoever*ln meddles in a quarrel not his own is*ld like one who takes a passing dog by the ears.
Like*ln a madman who throws firebrands, arrows, and death
is*ln the man who deceives his neighbor and*ld says, “I am only joking!”
For*ln lack of wood the fire goes out, and*ld where there is no whisperer, quarreling ceases.
As*ln charcoal to hot embers and wood to fire, so*ld is a quarrelsome man for kindling strife.
The*ln words of a whisperer are like delicious morsels; they*ld go down into the inner parts of the body.
Like*ln the glaze covering an earthen vessel are*ld fervent lips with an evil heart.
Whoever*ln hates disguises himself with his lips and*ld harbors deceit in his heart;
when*ln he speaks graciously, believe him not, for*ld there are seven abominations in his heart;
though*ln his hatred be covered with deception, his*ld wickedness will be exposed in the assembly.
Whoever*ln digs a pit will fall into it, and*ld a stone will come back on him who starts it rolling.
A*ln lying tongue hates its victims, and*ld a flattering mouth works ruin.
